Headline.Para: A Year Out, a Haze Still Surrounds Brexit; U.K. attempts to fudge the question of future relations could falter on the internal Irish border

LeadPara.Para: With one year to go until the U.K. leaves the European Union, the best that can be said for Brexit is that so far things haven't turned out quite as bad as feared. Never mind that the economy has slumped from close to the top of the advanced-economy growth league to the bottom. At least Britain's economy has grown by 1.7% in 2017 and unemployment fell, contrary to some of the bleaker pre-referendum forecasts.

TailParas.Para: Of course, that is partly due to the strength of the eurozone economy, which outperformed similarly gloomy forecasts. That suggests it was the eurozone rather than Brexit that economists misdiagnosed. The U.K. should be grateful it remains shackled to this unlikely tiger.

Britain's comparatively lackluster performance reflects uncertainty, of course, and the longer it persists, the greater the damage: Lower investment now translates into weaker productivity growth in the future. The central challenge facing the U.K. is therefore how to end the uncertainty and bring clarity to the Brexit process.
That's no simple task. The transition deal Prime Minister Theresa May struck in Brussels last week won't do the job. It merely defers the cliff-edge from March 29, 2019, to January 1, 2021.

Businesses are already warning that even 33 months may not be long enough to prepare for new border arrangements, a point Mrs. May all but conceded in Parliament on Tuesday. A delegation of worried Dutch business leaders from the Netherlands, which has already hired 750 new border officers in anticipation of Brexit, was in London this week expressing concern at the lack of U.K. preparations and pleading with British officials to provide clarity.

This question of how to quell Brexit uncertainty is dominating EU political debates too. Officials on the continent worry that a year after triggering Article 50 to start the two-year countdown to leaving, the U.K. still isn't facing up to reality.

Mrs. May's Mansion House speech last month brought a welcome change of tone but was still unrealistic in the eyes of EU officials. At its core were have-cake-and-eat-it proposals for mutual recognition of regulatory standards and U.K. membership of EU agencies. Brussels insists those arrangements are simply impossible for third countries not bound by the EU treaties and outside the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice.

Worse, Brussels officials say the U.K. government has totally changed its position since the autumn, when it was still insisting that it wanted complete agreement on the future relationship as part of next year's formal withdrawal agreement. "Now they want only a fluffy 10-page political declaration," a senior official says. "A detailed agreement would show how far the future relationship is inferior to membership. It would slaughter all unicorns."
The crunch will come at the EU Council summit in June, when the bloc's leaders must decide how far to push the U.K. They have two ways to try to force Britain to abandon fluffiness.

The first is to insist on a detailed political declaration setting out the framework for the future relationship in the withdrawal agreement. The second is via the vexed question of the Irish border, which can only be solved by coming up with answers on future regulatory alignment and customs arrangements that will eliminate the need for physical infrastructure.

Brussels has, in fact, given itself the means to force the U.K. to provide clarity on the Irish question: Ahead of last week's summit, Mrs. May accepted EU demands that the final agreement include a backstop solution that lets Northern Ireland remain aligned with EU customs and single-market rules unless and until a new arrangement is found. London even agreed to negotiate on the basis of the EU's draft protocol.

But will the EU really be prepared to turn the screw in June if little progress has been on working out the Irish backstop, or if the U.K. is still refusing to offer clarity over future ties? That isn't yet clear. EU leaders have only just begun to discuss how they see the EU's future relationship with the U.K. Some might be wary of putting the entire withdrawal agreement at risk if it appears that the British political system is simply unable to overcome its internal divisions.

After all, a "no deal" Brexit would be a disaster for both sides. Besides, the EU Council has never defined what it means by "no hard border" in Ireland, so it has wiggle room to accept a soft border with limited infrastructure if Ireland doesn't wield its veto.
On the other hand, EU officials say they have learned that Mrs. May only makes decisions at the last minute—and that under pressure she always makes the necessary compromises.

In this case, the concession the EU is seeking is an agreement from the U.K. to remain part of a customs union, which would address many of the problems over the Irish border and providing businesses with certainty.

They may, however, be misreading British politics. According to someone familiar with her thinking, Mrs. May is increasingly confident she has the votes to see off any attempt by Parliament to impose a customs union on the government. And she is said to be increasingly wedded to her own proposal for a customs partnership that would see the U.K. operating different regimes depending on whether imports were destined for the EU or U.K. markets—an approach dismissed in Brussels as "magical thinking."
But if the EU does hold firm, will Mrs. May really walk away? And would Parliament let her? The EU may calculate that the time to slaughter those unicorns is now.
